title: National Early Warning Score (NEWS) 2
description: Determines the degree of illness of a patient and prompts critical care intervention. Recommended by NHS over original NEWS with improved oxygen saturation scoring for hypercapnic respiratory failure patients.

parameters.name: respiratory_rate
parameters.description: Respiratory rate in breaths per minute

parameters.name: hypercapnic_respiratory_failure
parameters.description: Whether patient has hypercapnic respiratory failure (Type 2 respiratory failure, typically with CO2 retention)

parameters.name: oxygen_saturation
parameters.description: Oxygen saturation percentage (SpO2). Scoring differs based on hypercapnic respiratory failure status

parameters.name: supplemental_oxygen
parameters.description: Whether patient is receiving any supplemental oxygen

parameters.name: heart_rate
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

ranges.interpretation: Continue routine monitoring. Minimum monitoring frequency every 12 hours.
Assessment by competent registered nurse. Minimum monitoring frequency every 4-6 hours.
Urgent review by ward-based doctor or acute team nurse to decide if critical care team assessment needed.
Emergent assessment by clinical team or critical care team. Continuous monitoring of vital signs. Usually requires transfer to higher level of care.

references: Royal College of Physicians. National Early Warning Score (NEWS) 2: Standardising the assessment of acute-illness severity in the NHS. Updated report of a working party. London: RCP, 2017.

Pimentel MAF, Redfern OC, Gerry S, Collins GS, Malycha J, Prytherch D, et al. A comparison of the ability of the National Early Warning Score and the National Early Warning Score 2 to identify patients at risk of in-hospital mortality: A multi-centre database study. Resuscitation. 2019 Jan;134:147-156. doi: 10.1016/j.resuscitation.2018.09.026.
Smith GB, Redfern OC, Pimentel MA, Gerry S, Collins GS, Malycha J, et al. The National Early Warning Score 2 (NEWS2). Clin Med (Lond). 2019 May;19(3):260. doi: 10.7861/clinmedicine.19-3-260.
formula: Sum of points from: Respiratory Rate + Oxygen Saturation (adjusted for hypercapnic respiratory failure) + Supplemental Oxygen + Temperature + Systolic BP + Heart Rate + Consciousness. A RED score indicates any single parameter scoring 3 points.
notes: NEWS 2 differs from original NEWS by adjusting oxygen saturation scoring for patients with hypercapnic respiratory failure
A score of 3 in any individual parameter triggers a low-medium risk response requiring urgent review
Hypercapnic respiratory failure patients have lower oxygen saturation targets (88-92%)
New-onset confusion is now included in the consciousness assessment
